awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms of RNA Polymerase I Transcription Elongation
awd_abstract_narration:
This work seeks to fill a fundamental gap in our understanding of how one of the three specialized RNA polymerases, RNA Pol I, transcribes ribosomal DNA into ribosomal RNA.  This function is directly linked to cell growth and proliferation. The research will produce a detailed physical description of how RNA Pol I extends the RNA chain, and the findings will aid the broader scientific community in understanding why higher organisms have evolved three RNA polymerases, Pol I, II, and III, when lower organisms only require one. The project will also interrogate the role of subunits within this multi-subunit RNA polymerase.  Additionally, students will have opportunities to gain Ph.D. level expertise in enzymology, which is sought in both the public and private sector. Undergraduate students will also gain research training and become more informed and competitive for future careers in STEM fields. Finally, a specific plan is in place to support recruitment and retention of women in STEM fields.

Transcription elongation catalyzed by the fourteen subunit RNA Pol I is essential for ribosome biogenesis. Pol I synthesizes the 5.8 S, 18 S, and 25 S ribosomal RNAs. Despite its essential requirement for cell viability, little is known regarding the mechanism of Pol I catalyzed transcription elongation. This research will advance knowledge of transcription by producing a detailed kinetic mechanism for single and multi-nucleotide incorporation catalyzed by Pol I. Transient state kinetic techniques, specifically chemical quenched-flow and novel analysis methods will be employed to determine rate determining steps in the reaction and how these might be regulated. Substantial research has been done on DNA polymerases, bacterial RNA Pol, and eukaryotic RNA Pol II; however, much less is known about eukaryotic Pol I and III. The results of this project will enable comparison of the fundamental mechanistic differences between the three eukaryotic RNA polymerases, and help provide insights into the evolutionary pressures that led to their specialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organisms of the most populous domains of life, Archaea and Bacteria, employ a single RNA polymerase, RNAP, to transcribe all genes required by the cell. In contrast, eukaryotes have evolved at least three RNA polymerases, Pol I, II, and III, responsible for transcribing specific genes. Pol I synthesizes ribosomal (r) RNA, Pol II synthesizes messenger (m) RNA and most regulatory RNA, and Pol III synthesizes the 5 S rRNA and transfer (t) RNA. The basic mechanism for polymerization requires binding of the correct nucleotide and incorporation of this nucleotide into the nascent chain of RNA.  However, we do not have a complete determination of the rate-limiting steps and elementary rate constants governing the mechanism of transcription elongation for three eukaryotic RNA polymerases.   Knowledge of the elementary kinetic mechanisms of transcription elongation catalyzed by each of the three multi-subunit RNA polymerases will allow for a deeper understanding of the evolutionary pressure that led to three RNA polymerases.

In support of the hypothesis that the Pols exhibit divergent mechanisms, we showed that mutations in the trigger loop of Pol I (E1224G) induced loss of function compared to the reported gain of function for the corresponding mutation in Pol II (E1103G). We developed computational tools to streamline and improve the analysis of transient state kinetic time courses and made the code publicly available on GitHub. Thereby advancing infrastructure for research in biophysics, chemistry, and computer science.  We published a side-by-side comparison of single and multi-nucleotide addition, elongation stability and error frequency for Pol I, Pol II and Pol III. Pol I has emerged as a potential target for anticancer therapies. However, targeting Pol I requires high specificity for Pol I over Pol II and III.  We reported that mechanistic differences between the Pols can be exploited to design small molecule inhibitors and showed that Pol I is uniquely vulnerable to the small-molecule inhibitor BMH-21. Supporting the hypothesis that detailed knowledge of the rate limiting steps for each Pol has the potential to be exploited to advance disease therapies.  We published a detailed kinetic mechanism for Pol II catalyzed single nucleotide addition revealing that chemical bond formation is, most likely, the rate limiting step in single nucleotide addition for Pol II.  We advanced knowledge in chemical kinetics by publishing a detailed protocol on performing the single turnover transcription elongation experiments that can be applied to a variety of polymerases. Prior to this NSF support period we used transient state kinetics to determine the mechanism of single nucleotide addition catalyzed by Pol I and Pol I with A12.2 subunit deleted (Delta-A12 Pol I, the exonuclease deficient mutant). As expected, deleting the A12.2 subunit resulted in the removal of exonuclease activity. But, to our surprise, single nucleotide incorporation was observed to be slower and reversible in DA12 Pol I compared to Pol I. From that work we hypothesized that the A12.2 subunit does more than just provide exonuclease activity, but it also plays an integral role in each nucleotide incorporation.  Under this NSF support period we continued our work directed at the role of A12.2 in Pol I. The C-terminal domain (CTD) of the A12.2 subunit in Pol I is homologous to TFIIS, which confers exonuclease activity in Pol II. We showed that DA12CTD is exonuclease deficient consistent with the homology of the CTD of A12.2 with TFIIS.  To further shed light on the role of A12.2 in nucleotide incorporation we examined the multi-nucleotide addition kinetics for both Delta-A12 Pol I and Pol I. We concluded that, in Pol I, the A12.2 subunit evicts PPi from the active site after bond formation thereby inhibiting the possibility of catalyzing the reversal of bond formation.

This grant has contributed to the production of human resources.  It supported four Ph.D. students to completion.  It further allowed us to promote teaching, training, and learning. The PI and Co-PI have collaborated to produce a diverse, equitable, and inclusive training environment. Trainees working on this project are simultaneously trained in some of the most advanced techniques in molecular genetics, computational biology, and molecular biophysics regardless of their background. We have had the opportunity to mentor four female Ph.D students, two members of the LGBTQ community, two black students, and the PI is Hispanic. According to feedback from the trainees the lab environment is safe, equitable, and inclusive to everyone.  This grant has allowed us to enhance infrastructure for research and education by allowing us to maintain the presence of our lab with expertise in rapid-mixing kinetics (stopped-flow and quench-flow), analytical ultracentrifugation, hydrodynamic, thermodynamic, and spectroscopic approaches. The grant has allowed for the enhancement of education because the PI teaches both undergraduate and graduate level Physical Chemistry and Advanced Biochemistry, where our research in Molecular Biophysics is often incorporated into lectures in both classes.
